The synthesis of platform chemical 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) provides favorable and efficient paths for the utilization of renewable biomass resources. In this work, highly active niobium-modified montmorillonite (Nb-Mont) catalysts were synthesized by a facile and ion-exchange method and were used for the one-pot conversion of cellobiose and sucrose to 5-HMF with optimal results. 5-HMF yield of 68.6% was obtained from cellobiose in a methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK)/saturated salt water (SSW) biphasic solvent at 170 °C after 3 h. With sucrose as substrate in DMSO at 140 °C after 2 h, 5-HMF yield was 65.4%. The presence of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on Nb-Mont facilitate the hydrolysis of cellobiose and sucrose and play essential roles in the subsequent isomerization of glucose monomer and the dehydration of fructose monomer. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed for the transformation of cellobiose and sucrose into 5-HMF, and the isomerization process of glucose monomer was the most critical step, confirmed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. [NbO(OH)2]+ species as active sites could effectively reduce the activation energy of the isomerization process, which accelerated the synergetic proton transfer process. Nb-Mont was recycled at least four times without a prominent loss in the catalytic activity. In this study, a promising catalytic strategy was provided for heterogeneous Nb containing catalysts used in the effective synthesis of 5-HMF from carbohydrates. It is an urgent and significant mission to develop eco-friendly and sustainable energy resources [1]. Biomass could be well regarded as a renewable, environmental-friendly and cost-effective energy source, which produced directly or indirectly by photosynthesis [2]. Carbohydrates, accounting for 75% of the total available biomass [3], can be applied to synthesize a range of high-value-added platform compounds such as lactic acid, sorbitol [4], dimethylfuran [5] and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) [6]. Among these, 5-HMF as one of the top “10+4” biological platform compounds [7,8], can be widely used in the synthesis of chemical substances, due to the furan ring, hydroxyl group and aldehyde group in its structure [9]. As a result, 5-HMF has been considered to be a bridge between biomass resources and petrochemical industry [7]. There have been many reports on 5-HMF production from monosaccharides, mainly fructose and glucose [10,11], this is because monosaccharides as substrates can be effectively dehydrated to produce 5-HMF under acidic catalytic conditions. Compared with monosaccharides, the complicated structures of disaccharides such as cellobiose and sucrose bring a greater difficulty and new challenge to carry out the conversion process to 5-HMF, and the catalytic system for disaccharides should possess multiple high catalytic function for hydrolysis, isomerization and dehydration [12]. Nevertheless, the research on the catalytic converting reaction of cellobiose and sucrose has the instructive significance on development of high-value transformation technology for lower-cost polysaccharide such as cellulose, starch and inulin. Accordingly, the preparation of 5-HMF with cellobiose and sucrose as substrates have exhibited more widespread application prospect, and efficient conversion of cellobiose and sucrose to 5-HMF by catalytic method is a field worthy of exploring. Biomass-derived carbohydrates converting to 5-HMF is a characteristic acid-catalyzed reaction, that is, acidic catalysts play a dominant role in 5-HMF synthesis [13]. In general, acid catalysts can be roughly sorted into two categories: homogeneous catalysts and heterogeneous catalysts [14]. Specifically, the new advances of homogeneous catalysts newly developed at home and abroad, including organic acids [15], mineral acids [16], metal chlorides [17], metal triflates [18] and ionic liquids (ILs) [19]. Their catalytic activities are comparatively high, but there are some shortages, such as difficult recycle, corrosion and environmental pollution. Heterogeneous catalysts involve acidic resins [20], acidic zeolites [21], metal oxides [22], heteropolyacid salts [23], functionalized silicas [24], sulfonated porous polymer [25], functionalized clays [26] and carbonaceous acids [27], which show excellent adjustability, separability as well as recyclability and reusability; however, their catalytic activity for carbohydrates conversion are generally not high. Hence, further development in heterogeneous catalysts greatly contribute to the transformation of carbohydrates into 5-HMF. Montmorillonite (Mont) is regarded as a functionalized clay material, and used for modified heterogeneous catalysts due to excellent ability of adsorption, cation-exchange as well as adjustable acidity and extensible layer structure [28]. In this case, a lot of attention and interest are gradually attracting the development of modified montmorillonites as solid acid catalysts with high catalytic activity for 5-HMF synthesis. Tin-based montmorillonite (Sn-Mont) [29]. chromium-based montmorillonites (Cr-Mont) [26], aluminum-based montmorillonites (Al-Mont) [30], zirconium-based montmorillonites (Zr-Mont) [31], molybdenum-based montmorillonites (Mo-Mont) [32] and niobium-based montmorillonites (Nb-Mont) [33] are also be developed to catalyze the conversion of glucose and fructose with high yield of 5-HMF, among which Nb-Mont possesses many great and potential advantages, such as simple preparation process, high activity, low cost and good stability [28]. It was found that Nb species could effectively promote the dehydration process of glucose and fructose, and accelerate the hydrolysis of disaccharides [34–36]. In view of the good effects, the performance of Nb-Mont on one-pot converting cellobiose and sucrose were further explored, hoping to provide a greener and more efficient way for the synthesis of 5-HMF. In this paper, niobium-modified montmorillonites have been prepared using a simple and feasible procedure. Specifically, the catalytic activity of Nb-Mont on preparing 5-HMF from cellobiose and sucrose in single-phase and two-phase system was evaluated, and the optimum conditions were determined. Combined with density functional theory (DFT) calculation results, the catalytic mechanism of cellobiose and sucrose conversion to 5-HMF in the Nb-Mont-catalyzed system was further discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and instrumentation 5-HMF (98%), sucrose (99%), cellobiose (99%), maltose (99%) and montmorillonite purchased from the Aladdin Reagent Limited Company (Shanghai, China) were of analytical grade. Firstly, a certain amount of montmorillonite (Mont) was dispersed in ethanol solution with 30 min of vigorous stirring and 24 h static at room temperature to obtain the Mont suspension. Then, 0.5 wt%, 1 wt%, 2 wt% ethanol solutions of NbCl5 were dropwise added to Mont suspensions with dropping funnels, respectively; and the mixture was stirred continuously for 24 h at 40 ℃. Then, the solid catalyst was separated by filtration, and washed with ethanol at least three times to eliminate excess chloride. Finally, the Nb-Mont samples were powdered with mortar and pestle after drying at 100 ℃ for 12 h, then was named as 0.5Nb-Mont, 1Nb-Mont and 2Nb-Mont, respectively. Then, argon was flushed into the reactor for at least three times to eliminate the air, and then the reactor was pumped with nitrogen, which acted as a reaction protection gas. Furthermore, the reactor was sealed and placed in an oil bath with temperature controlled by thermocouple and was stirred at about 300 rpm. After a certain reaction time, the reaction mixture was transferred to the ice water to quench the reaction at once. Several characteristic bands were detected and assigned to the original framework of Mont. The adsorption bands at 1092 and 1038 cm−1 were related to the vibration of Si-O. After calcination, an adsorption band at approximately 1080 cm−1 apparently substituted for these adsorption bands, because of the interaction between niobium species and the framework of Mont layers [42]. No significant differences appeared, indicating the structure of Nb-Mont kept its original structural characters after the introduction of Nb. The pyridine-IR results of 1Nb-Mont and 1Nb-Mont-500 are shown in Fig. 4 . Two absorption bands centered at 1445 cm−1 and 1602 cm−1 were related to Lewis acid sites from metallic niobium species, while the band at 1540 cm−1 was relevant to Brønsted acid sites provided by Nb-OH groups on the surface of Nb-Mont. And the absorption band at 1490 cm−1 was bound up with the pyridine molecules adsorbed at both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [43,44]. Obviously, the relative ratio of Lewis and Brønsted acid of the catalyst calcined at 500 ℃ was much higher than that of the uncalcined catalyst. Compared with the raw montmorillonite material, the modified Mont catalysts also maintained the original lamellar structure (Fig. S1), largely uninfluenced by the added niobium species and the calcination process. The distribution of Nb and other elements in the 1Nb-Mont-500 could be clearly observed by HAADF-STEM image (Fig. S2), and STEM-EDS mapping exposed the partial substitution of Nb for Ca element and the uniform distribution of Nb species, conclusively demonstrating the introduction of Nb elements in the 1Nb-Mont-500 samples. XPS spectra (Fig. S3) of Nb 3d of 1Nb-Mont catalysts involves two characteristic peaks centered at approximately 207.5 eV and 210.2 eV that were assigned to Nb 3d5/2 and Nb 3d3/2, respectively, which are feature of pentavalent niobium [45]. XRF results (Table S1) imply that Nb5+ successfully substituted for Na+ and Ca2+ living in the interlayer of Mont. The introduction of Nb species into the Mont structure helps accelerate the stripping of the Mont laminated structure, leading to an increase of the specific surface area from 77.46 m2 g−1 to 125.33 m2 g−1. These results clearly indicate that the synthetic Nb-Mont catalysts possessed preferable properties, such as original well-ordered lamellar structure, Brønsted and Lewis acidity, and larger specific surface area. NH3-TPD quantitative results of Nb-Mont materials are shown in Fig. S4 and Table S2. Obviously, there were two characteristic absorption bands appeared in NH3-TPD spectrum of both 1Nb-Mont and 1Nb-Mont-500, which were in accordance with weak and strong acid sites on the surface. However, the acid density of the uncalcined Nb-Mont was much higher than that of the catalyst calcined at 500 ℃, which might be attributed that the calcination process promoted the conversion of polyhydroxy niobium to niobium oxide, thus reducing the hydroxyl group on Nb-OH group in the interlayer. 3.2 Evaluation of catalytic activity of Nb-Mont on conversion of disaccharides to 5-HMF Table 1 elaborates the performance of 1Nb-Mont catalysts in the one-pot preparation of 5-HMF from disaccharides. There were no 5-HMF formation and less than 30% disaccharides conversion without catalysts, demonstrating that it was difficult to synthesize 5-HMF from disaccharides without Nb-Mont (Table 1, entry 1). More than 30% conversion of disaccharides and trace amounts of 5-HMF were attained when utilizing unmodified Ca-Mont as a catalyst (Table 1, entry 2), indicating that Mont had a promoting effect on the transformation of disaccharides, especially for sucrose, possibly owing to assisting the cleavage of α-1, 2 glycosidic linkage. It is worth noting that sucrose was almost completely transformed and a 5-HMF yield of 65.4% was obtained with 1Nb-Mont as the catalyst, which was much higher than the yields of 5-HMF when cellobiose and maltose were used as substrates (Table 1, entry 3). The above results illustrated that higher selectivity for 5-HMF was obtained from sucrose with the catalysis of uncalcined 1Nb-Mont, higher conversions and 5-HMF yields of 68.6% and 41.4% were gained from cellobiose and maltose with 1Nb-Mont-500, respectively (Table 1, entry 4). Many previous studies found that Brønsted acid sites were active in the dehydration of fructose to form 5-HMF and Lewis acid sites had a conspicuous effect on the isomerization of glucose to fructose [46–49]. It is well known that the depolymerization of cellobiose and maltose to form glucose, the building unit of the above carbohydrate, followed by transformation of glucose to 5-HMF. Comparatively, the hydrolysates of sucrose are composed of fructose molecule and glucose molecule [50–52]. In this case, Nb-OH groups as Brønsted acid sites play a vital role in the reaction process of converting disaccharide into corresponding monomers. The subsequent dehydration of fructose molecule theoretically requires more Brønsted acid sites. Table S3 shows the semi-quantitative results of the amount of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid on the surface of 1Nb-Mont and 1Nb-Mont-500 catalysts. It is obvious that there were more Brønsted acid sites on the surface of the uncalcined 1Nb-Mont catalyst, and the ratio of L / B acid was much lower than that of the catalyst calcined at 500 ℃. It's the main reason that higher 5-HMF yield was obtained from sucrose with the catalysis of 1Nb-Mont, while 1Nb-Mont-500 was dominant in converting cellobiose and maltose. Interestingly, above 40% conversions of disaccharides and less than 1% yields of 5-HMF were achieved with using homogeneous NbCl5 as catalysts in the conversion of cellobiose and maltose (Table 1, entry 5), suggesting that homogeneous Nb5+ would induce the hydrolysis of disaccharides in the reaction, accelerating the breaking of glycosidic bonds. For sucrose, there was a higher yield of 5-HMF gained with NbCl5, in which Brønsted acidity played a key role in the dehydration of fructose monomer. Fig. 5 displays the effect of various Nb-Mont catalysts on the yield of 5-HMF from disaccharides. When the loading of Nb was 1 wt% on the Mont, higher yields of 5-HMF were obtained from three disaccharides, which might be due to the reasonable distribution of active niobium species in the interlayer of Mont. The optimum calcination temperature was 500 ℃ for 1Nb-Mont catalysts on the conversion of cellobiose. Table S4 sums up the results about the catalytic performance of different catalysts in the transformation of disaccharides to 5-HMF. Relatively speaking, Nb-Mont-based catalysts possessed more excellent catalytic effect than other catalysts, thanks to the introduction of niobium bringing larger specific surface area and stronger acidity. These results conclusively demonstrated the preferable catalytic performance of Nb-Mont catalyst. 3.2 Effects of temperature on the one-pot synthesis of 5-HMF from cellobiose and sucrose The reaction temperature has a remarkable effect on the synthesis of 5-HMF from sucrose. As shown in Fig. 6 (a), there were similar variation trends in the range of 0–180 min at different temperatures, which represented that the 5-HMF yield had a rapid increase up to a maximum value. And the higher the temperature, the faster the initial reaction rate. At 120 and 140 ℃, the yield of 5-HMF began to decline slowly after 120 min due to the decomposition of 5-HMF [53]. Apparently, the highest yield (65.4%) was obtained at 140 ℃ for 120 min. By further continued heating to 160 ℃, the yield of 5-HMF can reach to 50.39% in only 20 min, indicating that the increase of temperature favored the synthesis of 5-HMF from sucrose. Disappointingly, the change curve of the yield of 5-HMF decreased faster under 160 ℃ than under 120 ℃ since the decomposition reaction of 5-HMF also accelerated at high temperatures. These results indicate Nb-Mont possessed higher catalytic activity and stability in the conversion of sucrose. In comparison with sucrose, the effect of temperature on the preparation of 5-HMF from cellobiose was more obvious. As shown in Fig. 6(b), 5-HMF reached the highest yield within 5 h when the reaction temperature was 140 ℃ and 150 ℃, and it was later than that when the reaction temperature was heated to 160℃ and 170 ℃, in which temperature the highest 5-HMF yield was reached within 3 h. Continue heating to 180 ℃, and the highest yield can be achieved in only 2 h. Obviously, 170 ℃ of reaction temperature and 3 h of reaction time was the optimal reaction condition for 5-HMF preparation from cellobiose, exhibiting the highest 5-HMF yield (68.6%). The results revealed that the increased temperature favored the conversion of disaccharide to 5-HMF, but not the higher the better. However, the higher the temperature, the faster the decomposition rate of 5-HMF, which coincided with the conclusion of Xu et al. [12]. Hence, choosing an appropriate reaction temperature is significant for converting disaccharide to 5-HMF. 3.3 Solvent effect on the one-pot synthesis of 5-HMF from cellobiose and sucrose The solvent effect on the conversion of sucrose to 5-HMF is also significant when using synthetic Nb-Mont as catalyst. The influences of several common solvents, such as DMSO, SSW, water, MIBK, DMF, DMA and NMP on the yields of 5-HMF were studied. As can be seen in Fig. 7 (a), while in polar aprotic solvents such as DMSO, DMF, DMA and NMP, the 5-HMF yields were relatively high, thanks to the ability of these solvents to inhibit the side reactions and the stronger ability to dissolve reactants [54]. Hence, these polar aprotic solvents were preferable mediums on the 5-HMF preparation from sucrose. Though sucrose was soluble in water, Nb-Mont had a moderate catalytic activity when water was used as solvents, because 5-HMF was prone to further degrade in water and produce some byproducts, for instance, levulinic acid and formic acid [55,56]. Compared with pure water system, the yield of 5-HMF increased when SSW was used as a reaction medium. This is because the reaction rate was increased to a large extent with the salting-out effect of Cl− in solution, further increasing the 5-HMF yield [28]. The highest 5-HMF yield in DMSO was 65.4%. As a polar coordination solvent, DMSO was a superior organic solvent for the preparation of 5-HMF. Although water would also be produced in the reaction system, it was difficult for 5-HMF molecule to approach water molecule on account of the coordination of DMSO, the process of 5-HMF hydration to levulinic acid was inhibited, hence DMSO can stabilize 5-HMF [7,57]. To study the effect of solvents in the conversion of cellobiose to 5-HMF, a sequence of single-phase solvents and different proportions of two-phase solvents were used for the reaction. Fig. 7(b) shows that when water was used as single-phase solvent, the yield of 5-HMF was higher, nearly 30%, demonstrating that 1Nb-Mont-500 possessed stability and catalytic activity in water. Evidently, the 5-HMF yields in DMSO and NMP were much higher than that in DMA, DMF and SSW, which was similar to sucrose. The yield was extremely low when MIBK was used as solvent, owing to the low solubility of cellobiose in MIBK that was not conducive to the reaction. Notably, 1Nb-Mont-500 offered superior performance in MIBK-SSW biphasic solvents than in single-phase solvents since the fact that reactant and product were easy condensed in a single solvent, but not occur in a two-phase solvent. In addition, the effect of the ratio of organic (MIBK) to inorganic (SSW) phases on the yield of 5-HMF was also explored. The yield in MIBK phase was higher than that in SSW phase and the optimal volume ratio of MIBK phase to SSW phase was 7 : 3, in which ratio the yield of 5-HMF up to 68.6%, indicating that the capacity for 5-HMF molecules in organic solvent was better than inorganic solvent. 3.4 Optimization of reaction conditions for the one-pot conversion of sucrose to 5-HMF The effect of concentration of sucrose on the yield of 5-HMF was studied, shown in Fig. 8 (a). The highest 5-HMF yield was achieved when the concentration of sucrose was 35 mM, and 5-HMF yield decreased with the increasing sucrose concentration. This is because the overconcentration of sucrose would reduce the interaction between sucrose and H+ and cause cross-linking polymerization between sugar molecules to lead to the formation of humin, which is unfavorable to the reaction. In addition, exorbitant product concentration would also inhibit the reaction owing to reducing the effective contact area between sucrose and Nb species. Therefore, increasing the concentration of reactants could not increase the 5-HMF yield, and 35 mM of sucrose was the optimal concentration for this reaction system. In addition, the effect of amounts of catalyst on the yield of 5-HMF were also studied (Fig. 8(b)). Apparently, a higher 5-HMF yield was produced with 40 mg 1Nb-Mont than that with 20 mg and 10 mg 1Nb-Mont, which was because the hydrolysis of sucrose and further dehydration of monosaccharide can be effectively promoted with the stronger acidity provided by 1Nb-Mont. Therefore, the highest 5-HMF yield was gained the minute that the amount of 1Nb-Mont was 40 mg. Then keeping increasing the amount of 1Nb-Mont to 60 mg could inhibit the reaction due to the degradation of 5-HMF or the side reactions such as polymerization. Hence, 40 mg of 1Nb-Mont was applicable as the optimum amount of catalyst. 3.5 Catalyst recyclability The cyclic experiment at relatively low conversion 80% was performed to estimate its recyclability of Nb-Mont catalyst for the transformation of cellobiose and sucrose, and the consequences are showed in Fig. 9 . After the evaluation experiment, the Nb-Mont catalyst was obtained from centrifuging, filtering, washing and drying (100 ℃), and provided as the recycled catalysts directly used for the next run, in which the reaction conditions remained the same as before. In this case, it appeared that 5-HMF yield from the conversion of sucrose and cellobiose were guaranteed to be 40% and 30% after four cycles, respectively. Compared with the initial reaction, the slight reduction in the yield and conversion was mainly ascribed to that trace amounts of hydration by-products and humins appeared and some unreacted cellobiose and sucrose was overlaid on the surface of Nb-Mont during cycling. In addition, FTIR spectra of the recycled Nb-Mont catalyst was presented in Fig. S5, in which the characteristic peaks of 1Nb-Mont and 1Nb-Mont-500 almost unchanged after four cycles, indicating that the reusing processing had no breakage function to the structure of the recovered 1Nb-Mont catalyst in the transformation of sucrose and cellobiose. Through XRF analysis (Table S1), there was a slight decrease in the amount of Nb in 1Nb-Mont catalyst after four consecutive runs; these were also in line with a small drop in 5-HMF yield from cellobiose and sucrose conversion arising from the leaching of trace amount of Nb in the cyclic reaction process (Fig. S6). Therefore, Nb-Mont catalyst possessed favorable stability and excellent recycling performance for one-pot conversion of cellobiose and sucrose to 5-HMF. 3.6 Mechanism of sucrose and cellobiose conversion to 5-HMF Combined with the experimental results, a possible reaction mechanism of sucrose and cellobiose transformation to 5-HMF is proposed and depicted in Scheme 1 . The synthesis of 5-HMF from sucrose and cellobiose consist of three main stages, which involve hydrolysis of cellobiose and sucrose, isomerization of glucose monomer to fructose and three-step dehydration of fructose [58–60]. During the first stage, the protonation of oxygen atom on the glycoside bond causes a breakage of cellobiose and sucrose molecule to the glycoside bond to two monomers. That is to say, splitting sucrose molecule into glucose and fructose via the cleavage of α-1, 2 glycosidic linkage [61], and splitting cellobiose molecule into two glucose monomers via the cleavage of β-1, 4 glycosidic linkage [62]. The structural differences can also explain why the conditions needed from cellobiose conversion to achieve the same 5-HMF yield was tougher than that from sucrose in the above results. During the hydrolysis process, H ions required for this step are supplied by the Brønsted acid center from Nb-OH groups on the surface of Nb-Mont, and a few are provided by water molecules originating from solvents. The isolated mononuclear coordinated niobium oxyhydroxide species formed in the clays interlayer was simplified as [NbO(OH)2]+ model, giving a stirring performance as the dominant active sites, which could effectively strengthen the hydrogen bonding interactions between disaccharide molecules and Nb-Mont. The presence of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on Nb-Mont facilitate the hydrolysis of cellobiose and sucrose and play essential roles in the subsequent isomerization of glucose monomer and the dehydration of fructose monomer. The next step is the isomerization of glucose monomer to fructose, which includes three steps of cyclic glucose opening ring into acyclic linear glucose, enenol-ketone isomerization, and ring-closure reaction of linear fructose [63]. In the last stage, fructose molecules undergo dehydration reaction, and three water molecules are removed to form 5-HMF [64]. During one-pot synthesis process of 5-HMF from cellobiose and sucrose, Nb-OH group on Nb-Mont play a significant role, which might be not only the receptor but also the donor of the proton. For the synthesis of 5-HMF from sucrose and cellobiose, the isomerization process of glucose monomer is the most critical step, which comprise three steps based on previous work [28]. Comparatively speaking, the active species [NbO(OH)2]+ can effectively reduce the activation energy of isomerization process, owing to the increase of hydroxyl species on the active sites. Driven by the hydrogen bonding interactions, atoms of oxygen O5 from glucopyranose ring is attacked by Nb-OH group from [NbO(OH)2]+ species, resulting in the bond-breaking reaction of C1-O5 bond and the formation of O5H group. Simultaneously, the protonation of the adjacent terminal O atom of Nb-O makes getting H atom from O1H group, directing the C1=O1 aldehyde groups formed with an activation barrier of 8.82 kcal/mol (Fig. 10 ). Then immediately, an 1,2-enol structure as glucose intermediate (M3) generates in a similar way, which means O1 atom of aldehyde group is attacked by H atom of Nb-OH. The ketone-enol isomerization is a rate-limiting and endothermic process with 27.45 kcal/mol. The increase of hydroxyl species on the [NbO(OH)2]+ active sites could effectively reduce the activation energy and strengthen the hydrogen bonding interactions, which accelerated synergetic proton transfer process. The following second enol-ketone isomerization process with an activation barrier of 23.35 kcal/mol can lead to the formation of ketose structure, an acyclic fructose intermediate (M4). Subsequently, a proton transfer from Nb-OH to the carbonyl O atom of M5 helps facilitating a ring closure of acyclic fructose, giving rise to the generation of D-fructopyranose. Meanwhile, Nb-O as a proton acceptor gets a H atom from C-OH, leading to the recovery of the initial structure of [NbO(OH)2]+, which is endothermic by 8.03 kcal/mol. The subsequent three-step dehydration pathway for D-fructopyranose intermediate in the Nb-Mont catalytic system was also verified by DFT method. Under the interaction of hydrogen bonds, a rupture for the C2-OH bond on the five-member ring of D-fructopyranose is occurred by the attack of Nb-OH, resulting in the removal of the first H2O molecule and the formation of an unstable enol-form structure, which is further transformed to the aldehyde group on the branched chain. Simultaneously, the breakage of C3-OH bonds and C4-OH bonds on the ring promote the removal of the 2nd and 3rd H2O molecule through the hydrogen protons transfer from Nb-OH, respectively, assisting the formation of the final product 5-HMF and the recovery of the initial structure of Nb-Mont. DFT calculations indicate [NbO(OH)2]+ species as proton mediators play an important role in accelerating synergetic proton-transfer process involved in the conversion of sucrose and cellobiose to 5-HMF. 4 Conclusions This research provides a further exploration on the possibility of using Nb-Mont as effective catalysts for one-pot synthesis of 5-HMF from cellobiose and sucrose. The optimal 5-HMF yield of 65.4% and 68.6% could be obtained from the conversion of sucrose and cellobiose in DMSO and biphasic solvent, respectively. The active cooperation between the solvent water and catalytic site Nb-OH groups in Nb-Mont helped promote the hydrolysis process of cellobiose and sucrose with satisfactory yields in water. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed for the preparation of 5-HMF from sucrose and cellobiose, and the isomerization process of glucose monomer was the most critical step, confirmed by DFT calculations. [NbO(OH)2]+ as a dominant species could effectively reduce the activation energy of isomerization process, and the increase of hydroxyl species on the active sites strengthen the hydrogen bonding interactions between cellobiose and sucrose molecules and Nb-Mont, which accelerated synergetic proton transfer process. Hence, these findings offer an efficient and facile route that utilizes niobium-modified montmorillonite as multifunctional catalyst for one-pot synthesis of 5-HMF from cellobiose and sucrose. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of platform chemical 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) provides favorable and efficient paths for the utilization of renewable biomass resources. In this work, highly active niobium-modified montmorillonite (Nb-Mont) catalysts were synthesized by a facile and ion-exchange method and were used for the one-pot conversion of cellobiose and sucrose to 5-HMF with optimal results. 5-HMF yield of 68.6% was obtained from cellobiose in a methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK)/saturated salt water (SSW) biphasic solvent at 170 °C after 3 h. With sucrose as substrate in DMSO at 140 °C after 2 h, 5-HMF yield was 65.4%. The presence of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on Nb-Mont facilitate the hydrolysis of cellobiose and sucrose and play essential roles in the subsequent isomerization of glucose monomer and the dehydration of fructose monomer. A possible reaction mechanism was proposed for the transformation of cellobiose and sucrose into 5-HMF, and the isomerization process of glucose monomer was the most critical step, confirmed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. [NbO(OH)2]+ species as active sites could effectively reduce the activation energy of the isomerization process, which accelerated the synergetic proton transfer process. Nb-Mont was recycled at least four times without a prominent loss in the catalytic activity. In this study, a promising catalytic strategy was provided for heterogeneous Nb containing catalysts used in the effective synthesis of 5-HMF from carbohydrates.
